--- Comment #3 from <mailto:brodie.gaslam@yahoo.com|brodie.gaslam@yahoo.com> ---
Not sure if this helps or not but one difference between the classes you
mention and the ones that errors are reported for in dir mode is that the
latter are both defined and assigned to (unexported) symbols in the namespace,
e.g.:

```
StyleFunsAnsi <- setClass(
  "StyleFunsAnsi", contains="StyleFuns",
  ...
```

Whereas e.g. "Dark" is just defined but not assigned:

```
setClass("Dark", contains="VIRTUAL")
```

--- Comment #2 from Kurt Hornik (<mailto:Kurt.Hornik@wu.ac.at|Kurt.Hornik@wu.ac.at>) ---
If the Rd files in the man subdir of dir contain build-time Sexprs I
think you also need the partial Rd db in the build subdir of dir.
I.e., dir should be the root source dir of an unpacked source tarball
created from the master sources via R CMD build.

*[Bug 18919] [<-.POSIXlt and [[<-.POSIXlt do not reconcile time zones of 'x', 'value' before subassignment*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18919>

--- Comment #13 from Mikael Jagan (<mailto:jaganmn@mcmaster.ca|jaganmn@mcmaster.ca>) ---
FWIW, reconciliation of time zones without loss of precision seems easy enough
provided that 'gmtoff' is known:

```
asTZ1 <- function (x, tz = "") {
    ## stopifnot(inherits(x, "POSIXlt"))
    as.POSIXlt(as.POSIXct(x), tz = tz)
}

asTZ2 <- function (x, tz = "") {
    ## stopifnot(inherits(x, "POSIXlt"))
    xb <- balancePOSIXlt(x)
    xbcl <- as.POSIXlt(as.POSIXct(xb), tz = tz)
    off <- xbcl$gmtoff - xb$gmtoff
    xb$sec <- xb$sec + (off %% 60L)
    xb$min <- xb$min + (off %/% 60L)
    xb$isdst <- xbcl$isdst
    xb$zone <- xbcl$zone
    xb$gmtoff <- xbcl$gmtoff
    attr(xb, "tzone") <- attr(xbcl, "tzone")
    attr(xb, "balanced") <- NA
    balancePOSIXlt(xb)
}
```

Then:

```
> options(digits = 18L)
> xtz <- "America/Los_Angeles"
> ytz <- "America/Toronto"
> x <- as.POSIXlt(.POSIXct(1760994000, tz = xtz))
> (x$sec <- 0.11111111111111111111)
[1] 0.111111111111111133
> (y1 <- asTZ1(x, tz = ytz))$sec
[1] 0.111111164093017578
> (y2 <- asTZ2(x, tz = ytz))$sec
[1] 0.111111111111111133
```

But `help("POSIXlt")` documents that 'gmtoff' is not always known:

```
     'gmtoff'
          (Optional.) The offset in seconds from GMT: positive values
          are East of the meridian.  Usually 'NA' if unknown, but '0'
          could mean unknown.
```

In particular, on my system, I see:

```
> x <- strptime("2025-10-20 14:00:00",
+               format = "%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S",
+               tz = xtz)
> (x$sec <- 0.11111111111111111111)
[1] 0.111111111111111133
> (y1 <- asTZ1(x, tz = ytz))$sec
[1] 0.111111164093017578
> (y2 <- asTZ2(x, tz = ytz))$sec
[1] NA
> str(unclass(x))
List of 11
 $ sec   : num 0.111
 $ min   : int 0
 $ hour  : int 14
 $ mday  : int 20
 $ mon   : int 9
 $ year  : int 125
 $ wday  : int 1
 $ yday  : int 292
 $ isdst : int 1
 $ zone  : chr "PDT"
 $ gmtoff: int NA
 - attr(*, "tzone")= chr [1:3] "America/Los_Angeles" "PST" "PDT"
 - attr(*, "balanced")= logi NA
```

Maybe `asTZ2` could test for unknown `xb$gmtoff` and conditionally retrieve the
information?

```
asTZ2.fix <- function (x, tz = "") {
    ## stopifnot(inherits(x, "POSIXlt"))
    xb <- balancePOSIXlt(x)
    xbc <- as.POSIXct(xb)
    if (!isTRUE(all(xb$gmtoff)))
        xb$gmtoff <- as.POSIXlt(xbc)$gmtoff
    xbcl <- as.POSIXlt(xbc, tz = tz)
    off <- xbcl$gmtoff - xb$gmtoff
    xb$sec <- xb$sec + (off %% 60L)
    xb$min <- xb$min + (off %/% 60L)
    xb$isdst <- xbcl$isdst
    xb$zone <- xbcl$zone
    xb$gmtoff <- xbcl$gmtoff
    attr(xb, "tzone") <- attr(xbcl, "tzone")
    attr(xb, "balanced") <- NA
    balancePOSIXlt(xb)
}
```

One would need to verify that `as.POSIXlt.POSIXct` provides known `gmtoff` in
all cases ...

--- Comment #12 from Martin Maechler (<mailto:maechler@stat.math.ethz.ch|maechler@stat.math.ethz.ch>) ---
(In reply to Suharto Anggono from comment #11)
Yeah.. you may be right.   
I am considering reverting the back port and leave the R 4.5.x branch buggy 
i.e., keeping the wrong 5 hour time difference in Mikael's example at the top
of this PR, ..... ((which hurts my stomach slightly, too .. but then not longer
than the release of current R-devel in next April  ;-))

With one of your arguments (in Comment 9) I do strongly agree:  Even if
`c.POSIXlt()` currently works via `POSIXct` coercion and back, I agree that
this coercion and back with loss of precision is quite unfortunate and hence
should not be used as "role model" for other code.
A few years(?) ago, when I had thought about that (browsing code in R and C), I
came to the conclusion that it would need a considerable amount of C code to
"fix" the behaviour of current `c.POSIXlt()`  and I was not (and have notbeen)
not willing to spend the time to do that.

[Hint: anyone feeling like it may open a new bugzilla PR, notably if they are
willing  to work towards fixing this under the following constraints: 
  We do *not* want `c(<POSIXlt>, ....)` to become substantially slower nor 
  very much more complicated (code we must then maintain, ...) than now.]
